attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You should modify visibility of class or methods using getDeclaredConstructors(), getDeclaredConstructor(Class[]), setAccessible() or PrivilegedAction.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Accessibility Alteration

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods such as getDeclaredConstructors(), getDeclaredConstructor(Class[]) and setAccessible(), as the interface PrivilegedAction, allows for the runtime alteration of variable, class, or method visibility, even if they are private. This violates the principle of encapsulation.

Example(s):

import java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject;
import java.lang.reflect.Method;
import java.security.PrivilegedAction;

public class Violation {
  public void invalidCallsInMethod() throws SecurityException, NoSuchMethodException {
    
    // Possible call to forbidden getDeclaredConstructors
    Class[] arrayOfClass = new Class[1];
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructors();
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    Class clazz = this.getClass();
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructors();
    
    // Possible call to forbidden setAccessible
    clazz.getMethod("", arrayOfClass).setAccessible(false);
    AccessibleObject.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method[] methodsArray = clazz.getMethods();
    int nbMethod;
    for ( nbMethod = 0; nbMethod < methodsArray.length; nbMethod++ ) {
      methodsArray[nbMethod].setAccessible(false);
    }

    // Possible call to forbidden PrivilegedAction
    PrivilegedAction priv = (PrivilegedAction) new Object(); priv.run();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using assert as an identifier; it became a reserved word in JDK 1.4

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Assert As Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: System.arraycopy is more efficient

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Array Loops

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Instead of manually copying data between two arrays, use the efficient System.arraycopy method instead.

Example(s):

public class Test {
  public void bar() {
    int[] a = new int[10];
    int[] b = new int[10];
    for (int i=0;i<10;i++) {
      b[i]=a[i];
    }
  }
}

// this will trigger the rule
for (int i=0;i<10;i++) {
  b[i]=a[c[i]];
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using a branching statement as the last in a loop.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Branching Statement As Last In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using a branching statement as the last part of a loop may be a bug, and/or is confusing. Ensure that the usage is not a bug, or consider using another approach.

Example(s):

// unusual use of branching statement in a loop
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  if (i*i <= 25) {
    continue;
  }
  break;
}

// this makes more sense ...
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  if (i*i > 25) {
    break;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid calling finalize() explicitly

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Calling Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method Object.finalize() is called by the garbage collector on an object when garbage collection determines that there are no more references to the object. It should not be invoked by application logic.

Example(s):

void foo() {
  Bar b = new Bar();
  b.finalize();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiation through private constructors from outside of the constructor's class.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Accessor Class Generation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid catching generic exceptions such as NullPointerException, RuntimeException, Exception in try-catch block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching Generic Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid catching generic exceptions such as NullPointerException, RuntimeException, Exception in try-catch block.

Example(s):

package com.igate.primitive;

public class PrimitiveType {
  public void downCastPrimitiveType() {
    try {
      System.out.println(" i [" + i + "]");
    } catch(Exception e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    } catch(RuntimeException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    } catch(NullPointerException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  } 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An Interface should be used only to model a behaviour; consider converting this to a class.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Constants Interface

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An interface should be used only to characterize the external behavior of an implementing class: using an interface as a container of constants is a poor usage pattern and not recommended.

Example(s):

public interface ConstantsInterface {
  public static final int CONSTANT1=0;
  public static final String CONSTANT2="1";
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid catching NullPointerException; consider removing the cause of the NPE.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching NPE

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code should never throw NullPointerExceptions under normal circumstances. A catch block may hide the original error, causing other, more subtle problems later on.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    try {
      // do something
    } catch (NullPointerException npe) {
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement should never catch throwable since it includes errors.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching Throwable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catching Throwable errors is not recommended since its scope is very broad. It includes runtime issues such as OutOfMemoryError that should be exposed and managed separately.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  } catch (Throwable th) { // should not catch Throwable
    th.printStackTrace();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This abstract class does not have any abstract methods

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Class Without Abstract Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. An abstract class suggests an incomplete implementation, which is to be completed by subclasses implementing the abstract methods. If the class is intended to be used as a base class only (not to be instantiated directly) a protected constructor can be provided prevent direct instantiation.

Example(s):

public abstract class Foo {
  void int method1() { /*...*/ }
  void int method2() { /*...*/ }
  // consider using abstract methods or removing
  // the abstract modifier and adding protected constructors
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid appending characters as strings in StringBuffer.append.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Append Character With Char

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The String literal {0} appears {1} times in this file; the first occurrence is on line {2}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Duplicate Literals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code containing duplicate String literals can usually be improved by declaring the String as a constant field.

Example(s):

private void bar() {
  buz("Howdy");
  buz("Howdy");
  buz("Howdy");
  buz("Howdy");
}
private void buz(String x) {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid creating BigDecimal with a decimal (float/double) literal. Use a String literal

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Decimal Literals In Big Decimal Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
One might assume that the result of "new BigDecimal(0.1)" is exactly equal to 0.1, but it is actually equal to .1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is because 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double (or as a binary fraction of any finite length). Thus, the long value that is being passed in to the constructor is not exactly equal to 0.1, appearances notwithstanding. The (String) constructor, on the other hand, is perfectly predictable: 'new BigDecimal("0.1")' is exactly equal to 0.1, as one would expect. Therefore, it is generally recommended that the (String) constructor be used in preference to this one.

Example(s):

BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(1.123);    // loss of precision, this would trigger the rule
BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal("1.123");  // preferred approach
BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(12);       // preferred approach, ok for integer values

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Deeply Nested If Stmts

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Dollar Signs

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names.

Example(s):

public class Fo$o { // not a recommended name
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using enum as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.5

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Enum As Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Do not add empty strings

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Add Empty String

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The conversion of literals to strings by concatenating them with empty strings is inefficient. It is much better to use one of the type-specific toString() methods instead.

Example(s):

String s = "" + 123;                // inefficient 
String t = Integer.toString(456);   // preferred approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using final local variables, turn them into fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Final Local Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Field {0} has the same name as a method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Field Name Matching Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
It can be confusing to have a field name with the same name as a method. While this is permitted, having information (field) and actions (method) is not clear naming. Developers versed in Smalltalk often prefer this approach as the methods denote accessor methods.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  Object bar;
  // bar is data or an action or both?
  void bar() {
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Field Name Matching Type Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name. This probably means that type and/or field names should be chosen more carefully.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Bar {
  int foo; // There is probably a better name that can be used
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An instanceof check is being performed on the caught exception. Create a separate catch clause for this exception type.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Instanceof Checks In Catch Clause

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause.

Example(s):

try { // Avoid this
  // do something
} catch (Exception ee) {
  if (ee instanceof IOException) {
    cleanup();
  }
}

try { // Prefer this:
  // do something
} catch (IOException ee) {
  cleanup();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid assignments in operands

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assignment In Operand

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  int x = 2;
  if ((x = getX()) == 3) {
    System.out.println("3!");
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating new objects inside loops

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Instantiating Objects In Loops

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The user-supplied array ''{0}'' is stored directly.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Is Stored Directly

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Constructors and methods receiving arrays should clone objects and store the copy. This prevents future changes from the user from affecting the original array.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private String [] x;
  public void foo (String [] param) {
    // Don't do this, make a copy of the array at least
    this.x=param;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid statements in a catch block that invoke accessors on the exception without using the information

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Losing Exception Information

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Statements in a catch block that invoke accessors on the exception without using the information only add to code size. Either remove the invocation, or use the return result.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  } catch (SomeException se) {
    se.getMessage();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using Literals in Conditional Statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Literals In If Condition

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Each class should declare at least one constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: At Least One Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Using multiple unary operators may be a bug, and/or is confusing.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Multiple Unary Operators

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The use of multiple unary operators may be problematic, and/or confusing. Ensure that the intended usage is not a bug, or consider simplifying the expression.

Example(s):

// These are typo bugs, or at best needlessly complex and confusing:
int i = - -1;
int j = + - +1;
int z = ~~2;
boolean b = !!true;
boolean c = !!!true;

// These are better:
int i = 1;
int j = -1;
int z = 2;
boolean b = true;
boolean c = false;

// And these just make your brain hurt:
int i = ~-2;
int j = -~7;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Naming

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'.
Example(s):

public abstract class Foo { // should be AbstractFoo
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid protected fields in a final class. Change to private or package access.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Protected Field In Final Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use protected fields in final classes since they cannot be subclassed. Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

Example(s):

public final class Bar {
  private int x;
  protected int y;  // bar cannot be subclassed, so is y really private or package visible?

  Bar() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid protected methods in a final class that doesn't extend anything other than Object. Change to private or package access.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Protected Method In Final Class Not Extending

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use protected methods in most final classes since they cannot be subclassed. This should only be allowed in final classes that extend other classes with protected methods (whose visibility cannot be reduced). Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

Example(s):

public final class Foo {
  private int bar() {}

  protected int baz() {} // Foo cannot be subclassed, and doesn't extend anything, 
                         // so is baz() really private or package visible? 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid prefixing parameters by in, out or inOut. Uses Javadoc to document this behavior.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Prefixing Method Parameters

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Prefixing parameters by 'in' or 'out' pollutes the name of the parameters and reduces code readability. To indicate whether or not a parameter will be modify in a method, its better to document method behavior with Javadoc.

Example(s):

// Not really clear
public class Foo {
  public void bar(int inLeftOperand, Result outRightOperand) {
    outRightOperand.setValue(inLeftOperand * outRightOperand.getValue());
  }
}

Example(s):

// Far more useful
public class Foo {
  /**
   *
   * @param leftOperand, (purpose), not modified by method.
   * @param rightOperand (purpose), will be modified by the method: contains the result.
   */
  public void bar(int leftOperand, Result rightOperand) {
    rightOperand.setValue(leftOperand * rightOperand.getValue());
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Print Stack Trace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

Example(s):

class Foo {
  void bar() {
    try {
      // do something
    } catch (Exception e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement that catches an exception only to rethrow it should be avoided.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Rethrowing Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception only add to code size and runtime complexity.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  } catch (SomeException se) {
    throw se;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid reassigning parameters such as ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Reassigning Parameters

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reassigning values to incoming parameters is not recommended. Use temporary local variables instead.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private void foo(String bar) {
    bar = "something else";
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use block level rather than method level synchronization

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Synchronized At Method Level

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: StringBuffers can grow quite a lot, and so may become a source of memory leak (if the owning class has a long life time).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid String Buffer Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
StringBuffers/StringBuilders can grow considerably, and so may become a source of memory leaks if held within objects with long lifetimes.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private StringBuffer buffer;  // potential memory leak as an instance variable;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; it is not thread safe

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Thread Group

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; although it is intended to be used in a threaded environment it contains methods that are not thread-safe.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
  void buz() {
    ThreadGroup tg = new ThreadGroup("My threadgroup");
    tg = new ThreadGroup(tg, "my thread group");
    tg = Thread.currentThread().getThreadGroup();
    tg = System.getSecurityManager().getThreadGroup();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible unsafe assignment to a non-final static field in a constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assignment To Non Final Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Identifies a possible unsafe usage of a static field.

Example(s):

public class StaticField {
  static int x;

  public FinalFields(int y) {
    x = y; // unsafe
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement that catches an exception only to wrap it in a new instance of the same type of exception and throw it should be avoided

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing New Instance Of Same Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception wrapped inside a new instance of the same type only add to code size and runtime complexity.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  } catch (SomeException se) {
    // harmless comment      
    throw new SomeException(se);
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing null pointer exceptions.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Null Pointer Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing NullPointerExceptions. These are confusing because most people will assume that the virtual machine threw it. Consider using an IllegalArgumentException instead; this will be clearly seen as a programmer-initiated exception.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    throw new NullPointerException();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing raw exception types.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Raw Exception Types

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing certain exception types. Rather than throw a raw RuntimeException, Throwable, Exception, or Error, use a subclassed exception or error instead.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() throws Exception {
    throw new Exception();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not hard code the IP address ${variableName}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Hard Coded IP

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Application with hard-coded IP addresses can become impossible to deploy in some cases. Externalizing IP addresses is preferable.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private String ip = "127.0.0.1"; // not recommended
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The use of native code is not recommended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Native Code

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Unnecessary reliance on Java Native Interface (JNI) calls directly reduces application portability and increases the maintenance burden.

Example(s):

public class SomeJNIClass {
  public SomeJNIClass() {
    System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
  }

  static {
    System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
  }

  public void invalidCallsInMethod() throws SecurityException, NoSuchMethodException {
    System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not start a literal by 0 unless it's an octal value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Octal Values

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Integer literals should not start with zero since this denotes that the rest of literal will be interpreted as an octal value.

Example(s):

int i = 012;  // set i with 10 not 12
int j = 010;  // set j with 8 not 10
k = i * j;    // set k with 80 not 120

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not use the short type

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Short Type

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use of modifier volatile is not recommended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Volatile

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: No abstract method which means that the keyword is most likely used to prevent instantiation. Use a private or protected constructor instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Class Without Any Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If an abstract class does not provide any methods, it may be acting as a simple data container that is not meant to be instantiated. In this case, it is probably better to use a private or protected constructor in order to prevent instantiation than make the class misleadingly abstract.

Example(s):

public class abstract Example {
  String field;
  int otherField;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN. Due to the implicit lack of representation precision when comparing floating point numbers these are likely to cause logic errors.

Example(s):

boolean x = (y == Double.NaN);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A 'getX()' method which returns a boolean should be named 'isX()'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Get Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods that return boolean results should be named as predicate statements to denote this. I.e, 'isReady()', 'hasValues()', 'canCommit()', 'willFail()', etc. Avoid the use of the 'get' prefix for these methods.

Example(s):

public boolean getFoo();              // bad
public boolean isFoo();               // ok
public boolean getFoo(boolean bar);   // ok, unless checkParameterizedMethods=true

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; reference Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; you can reference Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE, or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

Example(s):

Boolean bar = new Boolean("true");    // unnecessary creation, just reference Boolean.TRUE;
Boolean buz = Boolean.valueOf(false); // ...., just reference Boolean.FALSE;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger and BigDecimal (ZERO, ONE, TEN)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Big Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger (BigInteger.ZERO, BigInteger.ONE) and for Java 1.5 onwards, BigInteger.TEN and BigDecimal (BigDecimal.ZERO, BigDecimal.ONE, BigDecimal.TEN)

Example(s):

BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(1);    // reference BigInteger.ONE instead
BigInteger bi2 = new BigInteger("0"); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead
BigInteger bi3 = new BigInteger(0.0); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead
BigInteger bi4;
bi4 = new BigInteger(0);              // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Found non-transient, non-static member. Please mark as transient or provide accessors.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bean Members Should Serialize

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Method call on object which may be null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Broken Null Check

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The null check is broken since it will throw a NullPointerException itself. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.

Example(s):

public String bar(String string) {
  // should be &&
  if (string!=null || !string.equals(""))
    return string;
  // should be ||
  if (string==null && string.equals(""))
    return string;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use bitwise inversion to invert boolean values

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Inversion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use bitwise inversion to invert boolean values - it's the fastest way to do this. See http://www.javaspecialists.co.za/archive/newsletter.do?issue=042&locale=en_US for specific details
Example(s):
  
boolean b = true;
b = !b;		// slow
b ^= true;	// fast

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Byte objects. Call Byte.valueOf() instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Byte Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer (or StringBuilder).append is called consecutively without reusing the target variable.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Consecutive Appends Should Reuse

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consecutively calls to StringBuffer/StringBuilder .append should reuse the target object. This can improve the performance.

Example(s):

String foo = " ";

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello"); // poor
buf.append(foo);
buf.append("World");

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello").append(foo).append("World"); // good

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: High amount of different objects as members denotes a high coupling

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Coupling Between Objects

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: This usage of the Collection.toArray() method will throw a ClassCastException.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Cast Exception With To Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When deriving an array of a specific class from your Collection, one should provide an array of the same class as the parameter of the toArray() method. Doing otherwise you will result in a ClassCastException.

Example(s):

Collection c = new ArrayList();
Integer obj = new Integer(1);
c.add(obj);
// this would trigger the rule (and throw a ClassCastException if executed)
Integer[] a = (Integer [])c.toArray();

// this is fine and will not trigger the rule
Integer[] b = (Integer [])c.toArray(new Integer[c.size()]);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Overridable {0} called during object construction

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Constructor Calls Overridable Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling overridable methods during construction poses a risk of invoking methods on an incompletely constructed object and can be difficult to debug. It may leave the sub-class unable to construct its superclass or forced to replicate the construction process completely within itself, losing the ability to call super(). If the default constructor contains a call to an overridable method, the subclass may be completely uninstantiable. Note that this includes method calls throughout the control flow graph - i.e., if a constructor Foo() calls a private method bar() that calls a public method buz(), this denotes a problem.

Example(s):

public class SeniorClass {
  public SeniorClass(){
    toString(); //may throw NullPointerException if overridden
  }

  public String toString(){
    return "IAmSeniorClass";
  }
}

public class JuniorClass extends SeniorClass {
  private String name;

  public JuniorClass(){
    super(); //Automatic call leads to NullPointerException
    name = "JuniorClass";
  }

  public String toString(){
    return name.toUpperCase();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: These nested if statements could be combined

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Collapsible If Statements

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Sometimes two consecutive 'if' statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator.

Example(s):

void bar() {
  if (x) {      // original implementation
    if (y) {
      // do stuff
    }
  }
}

void bar() {
  if (x && y) { // optimized implementation
    // do stuff
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer (or StringBuilder).append is called {0} consecutive times with literal Strings. Use a single append with a single combined String.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Consecutive Literal Appends

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consecutively calling StringBuffer/StringBuilder.append with String literals

Example(s):

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello").append(" ").append("World"); // poor
buf.append("Hello World"); // good

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone() method should be implemented only if implementing Cloneable interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Method Must Implement Cloneable

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Class names should begin with an uppercase character

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Class names should always begin with an upper case character.

Example(s):

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use equals() to compare object references.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compare Objects With Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Comment is required

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Required

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Denotes whether comments are required (or unwanted) for specific language elements.
Example(s):

/**
* 
*
* @author George Bush
*/

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Always check the return of one of the navigation method (next,previous,first,last) of a ResultSet.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check Result Set

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Always check the return values of navigation methods (next, previous, first, last) of a ResultSet. If the value return is 'false', it should be handled properly.

Example(s):

Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
rst.next(); // what if it returns false? bad form
String firstName = rst.getString(1);
Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
if (rst.next()) { // result is properly examined and used
  String firstName = rst.getString(1);
} else { // handle missing data
}

/**

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: super should be called at the start of the method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super First

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: It is a good practice to call super() in a constructor

attribute.value: Call Super In Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
Description

attribute.value: Call Super Last

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Check the value returned by the skip() method of an InputStream to see if the requested number of bytes has been skipped.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check Skip Result

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The skip() method may skip a smaller number of bytes than requested. Check the returned value to find out if it was the case or not.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private FileInputStream _s = new FileInputStream("file");

  public void skip(int n) throws IOException {
    _s.skip(n); // You are not sure that exactly n bytes are skipped
  }

  public void skipExactly(int n) throws IOException {
    while (n != 0) {
      long skipped = _s.skip(n);
      if (skipped == 0)
        throw new EOFException();
      n -= skipped;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid if (x != y) ..; else ..;

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Confusing Ternary

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: clone() method should throw CloneNotSupportedException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Throws Clone Not Supported Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method clone() should throw a CloneNotSupportedException.

Example(s):

public class MyClass implements Cloneable {
  public Object clone() { // will cause an error
    MyClass clone = (MyClass)super.clone();
    return clone;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A class which only has private constructors should be final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class With Only Private Constructors Should Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A class with only private constructors should be final, unless the private constructor is invoked by an inner class.

Example(s):

public class Foo {  //Should be final
  private Foo() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone() method should be implemented only if implementing Cloneable interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Method Must Implement Cloneable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method clone() should only be implemented if the class implements the Cloneable interface with the exception of a final method that only throws CloneNotSupportedException. This version uses PMD's type resolution facilities, and can detect if the class implements or extends a Cloneable class.

Example(s):


public class MyClass {
  public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    return foo;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Ensure that resources like this {0} object are closed after use

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Close Resource

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Ensure that resources (like Connection, Statement, and ResultSet objects) are always closed after use.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
  public void foo() {
    Connection c = pool.getConnection();
    try {
      // do stuff
    } catch (SQLException ex) {
      // handle exception
    } finally {
      // oops, should close the connection using 'close'!
      // c.close();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invalid words or phrases found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Content

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Found ''{0}''-anomaly for variable ''{1}'' (lines ''{2}''-''{3}'').

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dataflow Anomaly Analysis

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Double checked locking is not thread safe in Java.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Double Checked Locking

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Partially created objects can be returned by the Double Checked Locking pattern when used in Java. An optimizing JRE may assign a reference to the baz variable before it creates the object the reference is intended to point to. For more details refer to: http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2001/jw-0209-double.html or [http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/DoubleCheckedLocking.html]

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  Object baz;

  Object bar() {
    if (baz == null) { // baz may be non-null yet not fully created
      synchronized(this) {
        if (baz == null) {
          baz = new Object();
        }
      }
    }
    return baz;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't call Thread.run() explicitly, use Thread.start()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Call Thread Run

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Explicitly calling Thread.run() method will execute in the caller's thread of control. Instead, call Thread.start() for the intended behavior.

Example(s):

Thread t = new Thread();
t.run();                 // use t.start() instead
new Thread().run();      // same violation

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid duplicate imports such as ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Duplicate Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Duplicate or overlapping import statements should be avoided.

Example(s):

import java.lang.String;
import java.lang.*;

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid importing anything from the package 'java.lang'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Import Java Lang

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid importing anything from the package 'java.lang'. These classes are automatically imported (JLS 7.5.3).

Example(s):

import java.lang.String;  // this is unnecessary

public class Foo {}       // --- in another source code file...

import java.lang.*;       // this is bad

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Import Sun

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages. These packages are not portable and are likely to change.

Example(s):

import sun.misc.foo;

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The default label should be the last label in a switch statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Label Not Last In Switch Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar(int a) {
    switch (a) {
      case 1:  // do something
        break;
      default:  // the default case should be last, by convention
        break;
      case 2:
        break;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not explicitly trigger a garbage collection.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Call Garbage Collection Explicitly

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calls to System.gc(), Runtime.getRuntime().gc(), and System.runFinalization() are not advised. Code should have the same behavior whether the garbage collection is disabled using the option -Xdisableexplicitgc or not. Moreover, "modern" jvms do a very good job handling garbage collections. If memory usage issues unrelated to memory leaks develop within an application, it should be dealt with JVM options rather than within the code itself.

Example(s):

public class GCCall {
  public GCCall() {
    // Explicit gc call !
    System.gc();
  }

  public void doSomething() {
    // Explicit gc call !
    Runtime.getRuntime().gc();
  }

  public explicitGCcall() { 
    // Explicit gc call ! System.gc(); 
  }

  public void doSomething() { 
    // Explicit gc call ! Runtime.getRuntime().gc(); 
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: System.exit() should not be used in J2EE/JEE apps

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Call System Exit

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Web applications should not call System.exit(), since only the web container or the application server should stop the JVM. This rule also checks for the equivalent call Runtime.getRuntime().exit().

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    System.exit(0); // never call this when running in an application server!
}
public void foo() {
    Runtime.getRuntime().exit(0); // never stop the JVM manually, the container will do this.
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exceptions should not extend java.lang.Error

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Extend Java Lang Error

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Errors are system exceptions. Do not extend them.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Error { }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not hardcode /sdcard.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Hard Code SDCard

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A throw statement in a finally block makes the control flow hard to understand.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Throw Exception In Finally

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Throwing exceptions within a 'finally' block is confusing since they may mask other exceptions or code defects. Note: This is a PMD implementation of the Lint4j rule "A throw in a finally block"

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    try {
      // Here do some stuff
    } catch( Exception e) {
      // Handling the issue
    } finally {
      // is this really a good idea ?
      throw new Exception();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: To be compliant to J2EE, a webapp should not use any thread.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Use Threads

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use explicit scoping instead of the default package private level

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Use explicit scoping instead of the default package private level.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Use Float Type For Loop Indices

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Don't use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double unless you're certain that float provides enough precision and you have a compelling performance need (space or time).

Example(s):

public class Count {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    final int START = 2000000000;
    int count = 0;
    for (float f = START; f < START + 50; f++)
      count++;
    //Prints 0 because (float) START == (float) (START + 50).
    System.out.println(count);
    //The termination test misbehaves due to floating point granularity.
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using exceptions as flow control.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Exception As Flow Control

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using Exceptions as form of flow control is not recommended as they obscure true exceptions when debugging. Either add the necessary validation or use an alternate control structure.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  try {
    try {
    } catch (Exception e) {
      throw new WrapperException(e);
      // this is essentially a GOTO to the WrapperException catch block
    }
  } catch (WrapperException e) {
    // do some more stuff
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty catch blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Catch Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty Catch Block finds instances where an exception is caught, but nothing is done. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

Example(s):

public void doSomething() {
  try {
    FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("/tmp/bugger");
  } catch (IOException ioe) {
    // not good
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid really long classes.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Class Length

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty finalize methods

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Finalizer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty finalize methods serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  protected void finalize() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty finally blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Finally Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty finally blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    try {
      int x=2;
    } finally {
      // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A high number of imports can indicate a high degree of coupling within an object.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'if' statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty If Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty If Statement finds instances where a condition is checked but nothing is done about it.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
 void bar(int x) {
    if (x == 0) {
      // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An empty method in an abstract class should be abstract instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Method In Abstract Class Should Be Abstract

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty methods in an abstract class should be tagged as abstract. This helps to remove their inappropriate usage by developers who should be implementing their own versions in the concrete subclasses.

Example(s):

public abstract class ShouldBeAbstract {
  public Object couldBeAbstract() {
    // Should be abstract method ?
    return null;
  }

  public void couldBeAbstract() {
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid really long methods.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Method Length

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using equals() to compare against null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Tests for null should not use the equals() method. The '==' operator should be used instead.

Example(s):

String x = "foo";

if (x.equals(null)) { // bad form
  doSomething();
}

if (x == null) { // preferred
  doSomething();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to explicitly extend Object.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Extends Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
No need to explicitly extend Object.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Object { // not required
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This class has a bunch of public methods and attributes

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Public Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid long parameter lists.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Parameter List

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty synchronized blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Synchronized Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty synchronized blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    synchronized (this) {
      // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty static initializer was found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Static Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An empty static initializer serves no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  static {
    // empty
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An empty statement (semicolon) not part of a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Statement Not In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An empty statement (or a semicolon by itself) that is not used as the sole body of a 'for' or 'while' loop is probably a bug. It could also be a double semicolon, which has no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public void doit() {
  // this is probably not what you meant to do
  ;
  // the extra semicolon here this is not necessary
  System.out.println("look at the extra semicolon");;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty switch statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Switch Statements

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty switch statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
  int x = 2;
  switch (x) {
    // once there was code here
    // but it's been commented out or something
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty try blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Try Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid empty try blocks - what's the point?

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    try {
    } catch (Exception e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'while' statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty While Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty While Statement finds all instances where a while statement does nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it is a while loop that does a lot in the exit expression, rewrite it to make it clearer.

Example(s):

void bar(int a, int b) {
  while (a == b) {
    // empty!
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty initializer was found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty block statements.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Statement Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty block statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private int _bar;

  public void setBar(int bar) {
    { _bar = bar; } // Why not?
    {}              // But remove this.
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Last statement in finalize method should be a call to super.finalize()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Does Not Call Super Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If the finalize() is implemented, its last action should be to call super.finalize.

Example(s):

protected void finalize() {
  something();
  // neglected to call super.finalize()
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Declarations Should Be At Start Of Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.

Example(s):

public class HelloWorldBean {

  // Field declared before methods / inner classes - OK
  private String _thing;

  public String getMessage() {
    return "Hello World!";
  }

  // Field declared after methods / inner classes - avoid this
  private String _fieldInWrongLocation;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This final field could be made static

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Final Field Could Be Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If a final field is assigned to a compile-time constant, it could be made static, thus saving overhead in each object at runtime.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public final int BAR = 42; // this could be static and save some space
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loops Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using 'for' statements without using curly braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s):

for (int i = 0; i < 42; i++)
  foo();

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This for loop could be simplified to a while loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loop Should Be While Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Some for loops can be simplified while loops, this makes them more concise.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    for (;true;) true; // No Init or Update part, may as well be: while (true)
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalize methods should not be overloaded

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Overloaded

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods named finalize() should not have parameters. It is confusing and most likely an attempt to overload Object.finalize(). It will not be called by the VM.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  // this is confusing and probably a bug
  protected void finalize(int a) {
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalize should do something besides just calling super.finalize()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Only Calls Super Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If the finalize() is implemented, it should do something besides just calling super.finalize().

Example(s):

protected void finalize() {
  super.finalize();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: If you override finalize(), make it protected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Should Be Protected

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When overriding the finalize(), the new method should be set as protected. If made public, other classes may invoke it at inappropriate times.

Example(s):

public void finalize() {
  // do something
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible God class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: God Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The God Class rule detects the God Class design flaw using metrics. God classes do too many things, are very big and overly complex. They should be split apart to be more object-oriented. The rule uses the detection strategy described in "Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice". The violations are reported against the entire class. See also the references: Michele Lanza and Radu Marinescu. Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice: Using Software Metrics to Characterize, Evaluate, and Improve the Design of Object-Oriented Systems. Springer, Berlin, 1 edition, October 2006. Page 80.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: debug logging that involves string concatenation should be guarded with isDebugEnabled() checks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guard Debug Logging

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When log messages are composed by concatenating strings, the whole section should be guarded by a isDebugEnabled() check to avoid performance and memory issues.

Example(s):

public class Test {
  private static final Log __log = LogFactory.getLog(Test.class);
  public void test() {
    // okay:
    __log.debug("log something");

    // okay:
    __log.debug("log something with exception", e);

    // bad:
    __log.debug("log something" + " and " + "concat strings");

    // bad:
    __log.debug("log something" + " and " + "concat strings", e);

    // good:
    if (__log.isDebugEnabled()) {
      __log.debug("bla" + "",e );
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: There is log block not surrounded by if

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guard Log Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Whenever using a log level, one should check if the loglevel is actually enabled, or otherwise skip the associate String creation and manipulation.

Example(s):

// Add this for performance
if (log.isDebugEnabled() { 
  // ...
  log.debug("log something" + " and " + "concat strings");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: There is log block not surrounded by if

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guard Log Statement Java Util

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Whenever using a log level, one should check if the loglevel is actually enabled, or otherwise skip the associate String creation and manipulation.

Example(s):

// Add this for performance
if (log.isLoggable(Level.FINE)) {
  // ...
  log.fine("log something" + " and " + "concat strings");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Generics names should be a one letter long and upper case.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Generics Naming

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Names for references to generic values should be limited to a single uppercase letter.

Example(s):

public interface GenericDao<E extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> extends BaseDao {
  // This is ok...
}

public interface GenericDao<E extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
  // Also this
}

public interface GenericDao<e extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
  // 'e' should be an 'E'
}

public interface GenericDao<EF extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
  // 'EF' is not ok.
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: String.trim().length()==0 is an inefficient way to validate an empty String.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient Empty String Check

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: If Else Stmts Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using if..else statements without using surrounding braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s):

// this is OK
if (foo) x++;
   
// but this is not
if (foo)
  x = x+1;
else
  x = x-1;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Private field ''{0}'' could be made final; it is only initialized in the declaration or constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Immutable Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Identifies private fields whose values never change once they are initialized either in the declaration of the field or by a constructor. This helps in converting existing classes to becoming immutable ones.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private int x; // could be final

  public Foo() {
    x = 7;
  }

  public void foo() {
    int a = x + 2;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to import a type that lives in the same package

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Import From Same Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
There is no need to import a type that lives in the same package.

Example(s):

 package foo;
 
 import foo.Buz; // no need for this
 import foo.*; // or this
 
 public class Bar{}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Integer objects. Call Integer.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid idempotent operations (like assigning a variable to itself).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Idempotent Operations

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid idempotent operations - they have no effect.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    int x = 2;
    x = x;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid concatenating nonliterals in a StringBuffer/StringBuilder constructor or append().

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient String Buffering

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid concatenating non-literals in a StringBuffer constructor or append() since intermediate buffers will need to be created and destroyed by the JVM.

Example(s):

// Avoid this, two buffers are actually being created here
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = "+System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));
    
// do this instead
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = ");
sb.append(System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer constructor is initialized with size {0}, but has at least {1} characters appended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Insufficient String Buffer Declaration

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using if statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: If Stmts Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using if statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s):

if (foo) // not recommended
  x++;

if (foo) { // preferred approach
  x++;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Instantiation To Get Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead.

Example(s):

// replace this
Class c = new String().getClass();

// with this:
Class c = String.class;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid modifying an outer loop incrementer in an inner loop for update expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Jumbled Incrementer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid jumbled loop incrementers - it's usually a mistake, and is confusing even if intentional.

Example(s):

public class JumbledIncrementerRule1 {
  public void foo() {
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {      // only references 'i'
      for (int k = 0; k < 20; i++) {    // references both 'i' and 'k'
        System.out.println("Hello");
      }
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 indicates test suites via annotations, not the suite method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Suites Should Use Suite Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that clean up tests should use the @After annotation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use After Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that set up tests should use the @Before annotation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use Before Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that execute tests should use the @Test annotation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use Test Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit assertions should include a message

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Assertions Should Include Message

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
JUnit assertions should include an informative message - i.e., use the three-argument version of assertEquals(), not the two-argument version.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends TestCase {
  public void testSomething() {
    assertEquals("foo", "bar");
    // Use the form:
    // assertEquals("Foo does not equals bar", "foo", "bar");
    // instead
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You may have misspelled a JUnit framework method (setUp or tearDown)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Spelling

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Some JUnit framework methods are easy to misspell.

Example(s):

import junit.framework.*;

public class Foo extends TestCase {
  public void setup() {} // oops, should be setUp
  public void TearDown() {} // oops, should be tearDown
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You have a suite() method that is not both public and static, so JUnit won't call it to get your TestSuite. Is that what you wanted to do?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Static Suite

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The suite() method in a JUnit test needs to be both public and static.

Example(s):

import junit.framework.*;

public class Foo extends TestCase {
  public void suite() {}         // oops, should be static
  private static void suite() {} // oops, should be public
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit tests should not contain more than ${maximumAsserts} assert(s).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Test Contains Too Many Asserts

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
JUnit tests should not contain too many asserts. Many asserts are indicative of a complex test, for which it is harder to verify correctness. Consider breaking the test scenario into multiple, shorter test scenarios. Customize the maximum number of assertions used by this Rule to suit your needs.

Example(s):

public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
  // Ok
  public void testMyCaseWithOneAssert() {
    boolean myVar = false;
    assertFalse("should be false", myVar);
  }

  // Bad, too many asserts (assuming max=1)
  public void testMyCaseWithMoreAsserts() {
    boolean myVar = false;
    assertFalse("myVar should be false", myVar);
    assertEquals("should equals false", false, myVar);
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Tests Should Include Assert

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends TestCase {
  public void testSomething() {
    Bar b = findBar();
    // This is better than having a NullPointerException
    // assertNotNull("bar not found", b);
    b.work();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In JUnit4, use the @Test(expected) annotation to denote tests that should throw exceptions

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Use Expected

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using implementation types like ''{0}''; use the interface instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The Local Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'LocalHome'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Home Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The Local Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'LocalHome'.

Example(s):

public interface MyBeautifulLocalHome extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome {} // proper name
public interface MissingProperSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome {} // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use opposite operator instead of the logic complement operator.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Logic Inversion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use opposite operator instead of negating the whole expression with a logic complement operator.

Example(s):

public boolean bar(int a, int b) {
  if (!(a == b)) // use !=
    return false;
  if (!(a < b)) // use >=
    return false;
  return true;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Logger variable declaration does not contain the static and final modifiers

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Logger Is Not Static Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
In most cases, the Logger reference can be declared as static and final.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());               // not recommended
  static final Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());  // preferred approach
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Local Interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Local'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Interface Session Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The Local Interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Local'.

Example(s):

public interface MyLocal extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject {} // proper name
public interface MissingProperSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject {} // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Potential violation of Law of Demeter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Law Of Demeter

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use of ''{0}'' outside of package hierarchy ''{1}'' is not recommended; use recommended classes instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Package Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid excessively long variable names like {0}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Local variable ''{0}'' could be declared final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Variable Could Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using implementation types like ''{0}''; use the interface instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using implementation types (i.e., HashSet); use the interface (i.e, Set) instead

Example(s):

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.HashSet;

public class Bar {
  // Use List instead
  private ArrayList list = new ArrayList();
  // Use Set instead
  public HashSet getFoo() {
    return new HashSet();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Long objects.Call Long.valueOf() instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Parameter ''{0}'' is not assigned and could be declared final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Argument Could Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A switch statement does not contain a break

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Break In Switch

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Switch statements without break or return statements for each case option may indicate problematic behavior. Empty cases are ignored as these indicate an intentional fall-through.

Example(s):

public void bar(int status) {
  switch(status) {
    case CANCELLED:
      doCancelled();
      // break; hm, should this be commented out?
    case NEW:
      doNew();
      // is this really a fall-through?
    case REMOVED:
      doRemoved();
      // what happens if you add another case after this one?
    case OTHER: // empty case - this is interpreted as an intentional fall-through
    case ERROR:
      doErrorHandling();
      break;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Modified Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Modified Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: SessionBean or MessageBean should be suffixed by Bean

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: MDBAnd Session Bean Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The EJB Specification states that any MessageDrivenBean or SessionBean should be suffixed by 'Bean'.

Example(s):

public class SomeBean implements SessionBean{} // proper name
public class MissingTheProperSuffix implements SessionBean {} // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The null check here is misplaced; if the variable is null there will be a NullPointerException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Misplaced Null Check

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The null check here is misplaced. If the variable is null a NullPointerException will be thrown. Either the check is useless (the variable will never be "null") or it is incorrect.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    if (a.equals(baz) && a != null) {}
  }
}

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    if (a.equals(baz) || a == null) {}
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Returning ''{0}'' may expose an internal array.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Returns Internal Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Exposing internal arrays to the caller violates object encapsulation since elements can be removed or replaced outside of the object that owns it. It is safer to return a copy of the array.

Example(s):

public class SecureSystem {
  UserData [] ud;
  public UserData [] getUserData() {
    // Don't return directly the internal array, return a copy
    return ud;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class cannot be instantiated and does not provide any static methods or fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Static Method In Non Instantiatable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A class that has private constructors and does not have any static methods or fields cannot be used.

Example(s):

// This class is unusable, since it cannot be
// instantiated (private constructor),
// and no static method can be called.

public class Foo {
  private Foo() {}
  void foo() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Classes implementing Serializable should set a serialVersionUID

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Serial Version UID

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Serializable classes should provide a serialVersionUID field.

Example(s):

public class Foo implements java.io.Serializable {
  String name;
  // Define serialization id to avoid serialization related bugs
  // i.e., public static final long serialVersionUID = 4328743;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class contains more than one logger.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: More Than One Logger

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Normally only one logger is used in each class.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
  // It is very rare to see two loggers on a class, normally
  // log information is multiplexed by levels
  Logger log2= Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid naming non-fields with the prefix 'm_'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Misleading Variable Name

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Classes should not have non-constructor methods with the same name as the class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method With Same Name As Enclosing Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Non-constructor methods should not have the same name as the enclosing class.

Example(s):

public class MyClass {
  public MyClass() {}         // this is OK because it is a constructor
  public void MyClass() {}    // this is bad because it is a method
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method name does not begin with a lower case character.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method names should always begin with a lower case character, and should not contain underscores.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public void fooStuff() {
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Assigning an Object to null is a code smell. Consider refactoring.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The constructor with {0} parameters has an NCSS line count of {1}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Constructor Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A non-case label was present in a switch statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Case Label In Switch Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) was present in a switch statement. This legal, but confusing. It is easy to mix up the case labels and the non-case labels.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar(int a) {
    switch (a) {
      case 1:
        // do something
        break;
      mylabel: // this is legal, but confusing!
        break;
      default:
        break;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method {0}() has an NCSS line count of {1}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Method Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: All classes and interfaces must belong to a named package

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a class or interface does not have a package definition.

Example(s):

// no package declaration
public class ClassInDefaultPackage {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method {0}() has an NPath complexity of {1}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: NPath Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Non-static initializers are confusing

attribute.name: DisplayName
